title: SB 183
content: The State of California enacts the following. The Third Validating Act of 2015, also known as the Third Validating Act, defines "public body" to include various state departments, agencies, boards, commissions, cities, counties, districts, and other entities. This act encompasses a wide range of organizations, including air pollution control districts, airport districts, assessment districts, and bridge and highway districts. Various districts and authorities in California are included in the Third Validating Act of 2015, such as water districts, pest control districts, city maintenance districts, community college districts, and county boards of education. The Third Validating Act of 2015 in California includes a wide range of districts and authorities, such as water districts, drainage districts, fire protection districts, highway districts, housing authorities, and library districts. The Third Validating Act of 2015 in California covers various districts and authorities including irrigation districts, library districts, local health care districts, transportation authorities, maintenance districts, nonprofit corporations, parking authorities, port districts, and public utility districts. The Third Validating Act of 2015 in California covers a wide range of districts and authorities, including protection districts, public cemetery districts, water agencies, and regional transportation commissions. It excludes community redevelopment agencies formed under the Community Redevelopment Law. The Third Validating Act of 2015 in California covers various districts and authorities, excluding community redevelopment agencies. It defines "bonds" as instruments of indebtedness incurred for public purposes by public bodies. SEC. 3 declares all public bodies previously organized under any law to be legally functioning with all rights and obligations. SEC. 4 confirms the boundaries of public bodies as previously established. SEC. 5 confirms and validates all past actions taken by public bodies regarding annexation, inclusion, detachment, consolidation, merger, or dissolution of territories. This includes actions taken by governing boards and public officers. All past actions taken by public bodies for the authorization, issuance, sale, execution, delivery, or exchange of bonds for public purposes are authorized, confirmed, validated, and declared legally effective. All bonds issued by public bodies in the past are legally binding obligations, whether awarded, sold, or authorized through various actions. Bonds authorized by a public body through a voter-approved election are legally binding obligations when issued and delivered in accordance with that authorization. The act validates past legislative actions within constitutional limits and does not apply to ongoing legal disputes. The act validates past legislative actions within constitutional limits and does not authorize any act, proceeding, or contract that has been determined to be illegal or void. Any challenge to the validity of actions taken under laws for the formation, organization, or incorporation of public bodies, or related to boundary changes, bond issuance, etc., must be filed within six months of this act's effective date. Otherwise, such matters will be deemed valid and legally binding. This act does not extend the time limit for legal action beyond what is currently allowed. The curr_chunk states that it allows for legal action beyond the existing statute of limitations. The curr_chunk clarifies that changes in public bodies must be filed in accordance with specific government code sections for assessment and taxation purposes.
